channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Evacuations ordered as strong storm heads for Fujian Province
What to expect
item.description: Videographer James Reynolds speaks to Jonathan Mann about what he's encountering on the ground in Taiwan as typhoon Soudelor slams the tiny island nation.

item.title: Typhoon drenches Taiwan
item.description: CNN meteorologist Jennifer Gray has the latest on what the people of Taiwan and China can expect from typhoon Soudelor over the next few hours.

item.title: Did 'Granny Ripper' kill and eat 11 victims?
Theater shooter gets life sentence
Hostages trapped in Mali hotel siege
item.description: Soldiers late Friday surrounded a central Mali hotel where at least 10 gunmen were holed up with hostages, witnesses said, after a daylong standoff that left a number of locals, foreigners and Malian soldiers dead.

item.title: ISIS arming up for mass attacks?
item.description: Some in the U.S. intelligence community warn that ISIS may be working to build the capability to carry out mass casualty attacks, a significant departure from the terror group's current focus on encouraging lone wolf attacks, a senior U.S. intelligence officials told CNN Friday.

item.title: Fourth blogger hacked to death
North Korea creates own time zone
MH370: France steps up search
item.description: France is stepping up the search off Reunion for debris from missing Flight MH370 as Malaysia insists its investigators found more objects from a plane on the Indian Ocean island.

item.title: $181M cocaine found on sub
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard seized 12,000 pounds of cocaine worth an estimated $181 million when it intercepted a semi-submersible vessel in the eastern Pacific Ocean last month.

item.title: Plane bursts into flames on runway
item.description: A Delta-operated SkyWest plane briefly flared up on the tarmac of Nashville International Airport on Friday morning. The plane was heading to Cincinnati, Ohio, scheduled to depart at 6:34 a.m. CDT.

item.title: F1 driver 'gassed' in $500K burglary
item.description: Formula One driver Jenson Button's wife Jessica had her engagement ring stolen when thieves broke into a rented house in France -- in a burglary that a spokesman for Button suggested might have involved the use of gas.

item.title: Lightning hits hand-holding teens
item.description: California teens Lexie Varga and Dylan Corliss may do a lot more hand-holding after a frightening encounter with nature.

item.title: Russia burns banned brie, bacon
item.description: The Russian government banned food imports from Western countries last year in retaliation for sanctions; now, they're destroying food that has been banned. CNN's Matthew Chance reports.

item.title: Australia: 633 asylum seekers stopped
Child visits park, gets plague
item.description: An infected child is recovering in southern California after showing symptoms of plague following a camping trip at Yosemite National Park in July. KFSN reports.

item.title: TV, film icon George Cole dies
item.description: George Cole, the British actor who became best known in the U.K. in the long-running TV show "Minder" but also starred in major films including "Cleopatra" and "Scrooge" (released in the U.S. as "A Christmas Carol"), has died. He was 90.

item.title: Jennifer Aniston, Justin Theroux marry
item.description: Hollywood's most famous engaged couple finally appears to have made it official.

item.title: From 17,000 entries, 10 outstanding images
'Dark side' of moon caught on camera
This is your body -- up close
The man with a 5.5 hour commute
Spicy foods the key to a longer life?
Jon Stewart, in his own words
item.description: When Jon Stewart signs off Thursday night after 16 years of hosting "The Daily Show," he'll leave a a gaping void in the world of political satire.

item.title: 50 reasons Singapore may be the world's greatest city
Why did this CEO ban flip flops?!
item.description: Richard Quest looks at why the CEO of Barclaycard has banned flip flops in his company's headquarters and what counts as acceptable by business casual standards.

item.title: Why is Mourinho smiling?
Welcome to 'The Jungle' - inside Calais migrant camp
Knocked off her feet by a bomb 2 miles away
What Hiroshima taught the world
item.description: The world's first nuclear weapon was used in warfare 70 years on August 6, 1945 at precisely 8.15 am.

item.title: Japan FM: Why we must never forget
item.description: On August 6, 1945, a single bomb was dropped that took more than 130,000 lives in my hometown of Hiroshima, Japan.

item.title: Images: What the bomb left behind
item.description: A battered tricycle. Melted coins. A shredded shirt. Seventy years have passed, but artifacts and survivors still provide tangible links to the world's first act of nuclear warfare.

item.title: Bomb site attracts tourists in Japan
item.description: Seven decades after the U.S. military dropped an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima, effectively ending World War II, the site of the devastation remains one of the most popular tourist attractions in the country.

item.title: 'Money Man' Mayweather eyes one last payday
Did Man Utd strike it lucky in draw?
Meet the new kings of South America
Wow! Incredible natural swimming pools
The city that's giving voice to its artists
item.description: There wasn't much reason for anyone to venture into Savamala's neglected streets only a few years ago.

item.title: Asian cuisine's next big thing
Is this the world's most expensive car?
What if the next big thing in fashion wasn't wearable?
Finding beauty in imperfection
7 ways to spot someone is being trafficked
Opinion: The myth of child prostitution
item.description: Last week saw the premiere of "Children for Sale: The Fight to End Human Trafficking," which exposes the hidden realities of child sex trafficking in the United States. It's a powerful documentary. But there's even more to the story.

item.title: Countries ranked: Who's fighting trafficking?
item.description: Cuba, Kenya and Saudi Arabia are doing better at fighting human trafficking. Egypt, Ghana and Bulgaria are doing worse.

item.title: New Suez Canal a symbol of Sisi's leadership?
item.description: CNN's Hala Gorani speaks to the Council on Foreign Relations' Steven Cook about the current state of Egypt and the work being done by President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.

item.title: 'Whale Whisperers' wins Nat Geo contest
item.description: Sarah Polger discusses the most recent winners of National Geographic's traveler photo contest.

item.title: Six tons of cocaine seized from submarine
item.description: The U.S. Coast Guard intercepted a 40-foot homemade submarine carrying $181 million worth of drugs.

item.title: A painted journey in Singapore
item.description: CNN's Victoria Kennedy talks with internationally acclaimed artist and athlete Gregory Burns about his works of art.

item.title: Atomic bomb survivor shares survival story
item.description: Seventy years ago Chisako Takeoka survived the world's first attack with an atomic bomb. Since then, she has traveled the world sharing the horrors of her experience. Ivan Watson has her story.

item.title: Will Rio be ready for next year's Olympics?
item.description: CNN's Shasta Darlington takes a look at what Rio de Janerio is doing to get ready for the 2016 Olympic games.

item.title: Drawings show haunting memories of Hiroshima
Must-ride bicycle trips
item.description: The magic of the open road, trail or mountain has long captured the imaginations of cyclists, whether they are professional riders or weekend warriors.

item.title: 11 inspiring African proverbs
item.description: We asked our Twitter followers to send us their favorite African proverbs and tag them #CNNAfricanProverbs. These are 11 of our favorites.

item.title: For freedivers, the ocean can be unforgiving
Malaysia reckless on MH370 facts
Lessons from the ashes of Hiroshima
The king with 100 wives
Beirut's 1960s jet-set playgrounds
item.description: For several decades the name "Beirut" has conjured images of devastation and danger.

item.title: Buildings on verge of destruction
item.description: Go see them now, before it's too late: threatened by neglect, the elements, changing architectural trends or ruthless developers, these outstanding buildings are all fighting a hard battle for survival.

item.title: World's 10 most scenic airport approaches
item.description: For jaded air travelers, window seats are overrated.

item.title: Ruins of the Soviet space shuttle program
item.description: What was once the gleaming pride and joy of the Soviet space program now lies covered in dirt and bird droppings in a disused hangar in Kazakhstan.

item.title: NASA finds 'Earth's bigger, older cousin'
item.description: NASA said Thursday that its Kepler spacecraft has spotted "Earth's bigger, older cousin": the first nearly Earth-size planet to be found in the habitable zone of a star similar to our own.

item.title: 10 watches that changed history
item.description: Mechanical watchmaking is not a world of revolutions, it's a world of evolutions, where change comes only slowly and tradition is a sacred trust. In the five hundred or so years that watches have existed, however, there have been a few that have changed the watchmaking world. Some of these watches broke new ground in design, some in technology -- and some both. Here are ten that made history and became part of it at the same time.

item.title: Top 20 museums around the world
Girl from Vietnam War photo: Where is she?
item.description: Even without the benefit of context, the image of a naked 9-year-old girl running for her life is as searing and indelible today as it was 43 years ago.

item.title: Capturing beauty around the world
item.description: To photographer Mihaela Noroc, beauty cannot be defined by one country, race or ethnicity.

item.title: The homeowners who refused to budge
